fields.description:
I recommend we investigate replacing the current structure at *http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ALLDOC/Atlassian+Documentation* with something easier for customers. One of the issues I have seen is customers having difficulty downloading the correct version of the documentation in the format of their choice.

I was thinking a table along the lines of:

| Product | Online | PDF | HTML | XML |

With links to the latest version of the documentation in each of those formats. All of the references throughout CAC could then point to that for the downloads.
fields.summary: Improve Documentation Download Page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-10878].
  {panel}

Often confluence is used in a situation where many of the users come from different time zones. 

E.g. If you have the main office in Sydney, but a branch in San Fran. 

Daily reports are generated once and since the server is in Sydney, the users in San Fran will only receive it in the middle of the day.

If the daily report can be generated for users according to the time zone, so that they receive it before they come in to work. The users in Sydney and San Fran should receive it at different times and their reports will be different.
fields.summary: Allow the ability for the Daily report to be generated and delivered to people in different timezones

When creating a link to an attached file, the comments for the attached file should be visible in the selection window.

A comment can be created when the file is attached that is more descriptive than the filename.
When a link is being created to an attachment, especially if there a large number of attachments on the page, then it is difficult to choose the file that is desired in the pop-up window that displays.

Showing the comments in this page would help greatly.
fields.summary: When creating a link to an attached file, the comments for the attached file should be visible in the selection window.

fields.description:
In the scope for business wiki use, for those who create task sheets in the wiki (like a project list) it would be beneficial (or simpler than using strike-outs) to have clickable check boxes so that as a member of the project, I could go in and check a certain task.

Of course this opens the door of how to implement it, as edit mode doesn't make a lot of sense for check boxes, and somehow there would have to be some kind of dynamic save button that only appears on pages /w check boxes or perhaps AJAX that saves a check box's state upon it being clicked.  I could definitely foresee this feature making users eager for what user actually clicked the check box and perhaps that's something simply stored in the wiki markup of the check box.
fields.summary: clickable Checkboxes

fields.description:
Howto see this bug:
- Create a new page with any title, text containing German Umlaute. (my example: unternehmensänderung)
- Save the Page
- Wait until page is indexed

- Attach a file named unternehmensänderung.zip to this page

Now search for:
- unternehmensänderung (finds both, okay)
- unternehmens* (finds both, okay)
- unternehmensä* (finds only the attached file !)

Why can confluence search attachments for the umlaut combined with the wildcard, but not the page itself?

 I think confluence is a really good wiki, but a good search enginge is really important for the acceptance in a company.
fields.summary: Corrupt search with Umlaute

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-10845].
  {panel}

In one customer's environment, their virus checker occasional hangs the confluence server for up to 3 seconds. During one such time, a customer tried to add a page to favourites 3 times and thus when the server began processing, it ended up adding three rows into the content_label table. Now when trying to remove the page from favourites, it results in the error covered by CONF-13516. The customer should not be able to get into a situation like this. 

To prevent this situation, we can add more constraints on the database level.

A similar problem occurs with the content table for pages and blog posts. There are no database restrictions on page title + space key + version uniqueness for pages, so there's a race condition where two requests to save a page come in at exactly the same time, check for an existing version -- don't find one -- and proceed with saving the new version in duplicate.

However, implementing this in the CONTENT table is a tad difficult, where the restrictions would need to be based on the CONTENTTYPE column being "PAGE" or "BLOGPOST". We can't implement this in a database independent way with Hibernate. The CONTENT table would need to be split up by class to implement this for all customers, which raises a whole host of other problems.

Our current recommendation is that customers investigate implementing the database constraints themselves if they are interested in getting this additional level of security. In general, Confluence is designed to handle the duplicates gracefully rather than prevent them in the first place. (Hence CONF-13516 where multiple labels caused problems is fixed as a bug separate to this improvement.)
fields.summary: Additional database constraints to prevent erroneous duplication of the same row

fields.description:
Upon Confluence upgrade to 2.7 or later, admin may discover that the {{KEYSTORE}} table does not exist.

An upgrade misconfiguration is known to can cause this. For example:
{panel}
# Admin created a test Confluence instance of the latest version and new database, then shut it down
# Admin imported production database into this new instance
# Admin copied production instance's Confluence Home but kept the test instance's {{confluence.cfg.xml}}. This xml file contains the target version's build number.
# Admin started test instance in the hope that this will upgrade Confluence.
# Because Confluence see that the build number in {{confluence.cfg.xml}} is the same as the running Confluence version, the upgrade is skipped.
{panel}

Step 3 is wrong. The {{confluence.cfg.xml}} should also be reverted to the old build number ([click here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEVNET/Confluence+Build+Information] for Confluence Build Information).

{noformat:title=Sample error}
ERROR [DefaultQuartzScheduler_Worker-6] [confluence.importexport.impl.BackupExporter] backupEntities Couldn't backup database data.

Caused by: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.MySQLSyntaxErrorException: Table 'confluencedb271.KEYSTORE' doesn't exist
	at com.mysql.jdbc.SQLError.createSQLException(SQLError.java:1027)
{noformat}

fields.description:
See http://developer.atlassian.com/jira/browse/CPDK-1

The maven2 plugin executes the plugin upload, and needs to determine success or failure at a minimum.  Since the current xwork action redirects (302) upon success, and a login failure is redirected (302) by the container based on invalid credentials, there is no possible way to determine success or failure.

{code:xml}<action name="uploadplugin" class="com.atlassian.confluence.admin.actions.plugins.UploadPluginAction">
            <result name="input" type="velocity">/admin/plugins.vm</result>
            <result name="error" type="velocity">/admin/plugins.vm</result>
            <result name="success" type="redirect">/admin/plugins.action?pluginKey=${pluginKey}</result>
        </action>{code}

If this action is utilized by any pages, I would suggest an additional, dedicated xwork action to create a response that indicates success, failure, or even more information by an automated client.  I would assume that recognizing the 302 as a login failure is the best way to handle that issue, so no deeper or intrusive changes are necessary on the container.
fields.summary: XWork action "uploadplugin" must return a response that distinguishes success or failure (NOT a redirect)
